description.text:
I wanted a joystick for racing games with a knob as steering wheel and a sequential gearbox but not too big, so I removed the dust from my old "Microsoft SideWinder Precision Racing Wheel" from the '99 and destroyed it :)

Pedals for breake and throttle where removed completely (it was to complex to use them with potenciomenters).

Springs were taken from old DVD and Floppy drives.

Electronic Switches were taken off from the buttons PCB of the steering wheel and soldered out straight to cables into the main PCB (so I've got 4 extra buttons plus 2 to replace breake and throttle and 2 for the gearbox)

I thought to share this little project cause it could give you some ideas on how to create something similar but this build is specific for the joystick I had from Microsoft.

I've used 123D Design. Uploaded is the final file with the entire design.

I'm still thinking about it, after playing some time it needs some improve on the design and also buttons feel like "touch", they are too sensitive.

For the top part of the joystick is better to print how it will be and adding a lot of support to get a nice top surface (it's gonna be a lot of support)

Check the support for the little turrets of springs (for steering wheel) they wasn't auto-generated on CraftWare for me.

title: Intex Inlet / Return - Vacuum Hose Connector / Adapter

description.text:
This part will allow you to connect an Intex Vacuum Hose to a standard 1 1/2 inch female threaded inlet or return. This part can be used in place of the Intex Large Strainer: http://www.intexcorp.com/11236.html. I designed this part in OpenSCAD and attached the source. The washers are optional but recommended (print in flexible filament).

Printed in PETG 240C, 40mm/s, 100% infill, no raft, no supports.

Due to variations in printers and print settings you will probably have to modify the model. Please read the scad file for instructions.

Notes:
  • Material: SMARTMATERIALS FLEX
  • Bed: 50c
  • Extruder: 235c
  • Velocity: 25mm/s

These are the printable pieces of the Hello, Velo project on Instructables.

Hello, Velo is a device for making your bicycle more awesome! It contains a GPS and a SIM card, so it always knows where it is and can send and receive text messages. Forgot where you locked your bike? Send it a text and ask! Headed home from work and need to let your significant other know your arrival time? Hello, Velo can detect that and send the message for you.

I printed all these parts from PLA using support material. Orientation is not very important for the "holder", but the "collar" and "back" should be printed so that the ring is in-plane (to prevent breaking during mounting). The collar can be customized to fit your own bike's stem/seatpost/top tube radius; the default pieces I've included here are for a 36mm diameter stem. Note that it's a good idea to make this a bit big so you can put rubber or another material between to keep everything from slipping apart.

Note: using Customizer for this part can take a loooooong time. All the source for the parts is included in the one .scad file that is included in this repository.

title: Fifth Element Multipass Convention Badge + Card Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a convention badge and card holder I designed, inspired by the movie The Fifth Element. It is designed to be worn around the neck and contains an internal cavity to store a wallet-sized card such as a credit card or hotel room key card. The design incorporates two internal springs to make retaining and ejecting the card easy.
I have included a file of the unit completely assembled for reference, however each of the included parts should be printed separately and carefully glued together to ensure that the card holder mechanism works properly.

I have also included an ID template that you can use to customize and print your own IDs. It can be edited in inkscape or any vector image editor that supports .svg files.

EDIT: Thingiverse doesn't allow .svg files; a copy of the ID template is available at https://www.youmagine.com/designs/fifth-element-multipass-convention-badge-card-holder#documents

A youtube video showing how the card holder feature works is available below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZWHuZMWwYi4

Thanks to Tech2C for the original design. I just added the induction mount for auto bed leveling.

title: Easy to print FlashForge Creator Pro 50mm filament holder

description.text:
Update 2016/08/28: I have made a new spool holder with adjustable length. I highly recommend printing that one instead of this older model.

This is an alternative version of the 50mm spool holder by RonPossible, for the recent revisions of the FlashForge Creator Pro. This is suitable for filament spools with a simple cylindrical hole of 50mm diameter and 60mm length.

The differences are:

  • Ready-to-print support material is provided, with small tabs to ensure the overhang that will be printed on top, will not detach prematurely and fall off before it can be bridged with the rest of the print, as has happened when I tried to let Slic3r generate supports. I highly recommend to print this one. The photos show a successful test of this support material (I didn't print yet another entire holder because I already have two usable ones).
  • For those who want to generate their own support material anyway, there is also a file without the supports. This should still be less risky to print because I replaced the curved overhang with a straight one, which should make it easier for your slicer to provide good supports.
  • I thickened some parts for improved strength.
  • I added some holes to save a bit of material and speed up the print.

I only remixed the 50 mm holder because I don't have any spools with other diameters. If you want a remix of the 32 mm holder as well, just ask.

description.text:
A basic adjustable spool holder which clips onto the side hand hole on the 2015 FlashForge Creator Pro (may fit similar like Makerbot etc).
I had some old skateboard bearing so i figured i could use them - this is mainly for specialty filament that you dont want or need to feed through the feeder tubes - especially flexible filament - it just feeds straight into the extruder assembly.
Requires the following Hardware:

  1. 4 x (skateboard bearings) 608 bearings
  2. 2 x 150mm m8 bolts or threaded rod
  3. 8 x m8 nuts

Print the Left and the Right, then press the bearings in each side, slide the bolts through and your done! Can be adjusted for skinnier rolls if required and simply lifts off when not in use.

description.text:
I used to have a mobile unit, but someone broke into my SUV and stole everything they could get disconnected. I made this mount to so I can use my portable, and remove it when I'm not in the vehicle.

It has a flat bottom, and beveled screw holes, so mounting is easy on millions of surfaces, I made another one with my call sign on it for my Suburban, and this prototype unit is now in my Audi. If you notice in the picture, I'm not using screws, this was my prototype so it's just double sided taped using regular 3M tape. It also has a rounded bottom, I realized that was just me being silly so I made it flat. I remade it with my call sign, and 100% fill for strength (not that it needed it).

FYI...I know it looks close, but believe it or not, the shifter clears pretty easily because it has to lift out before going down into gear. This mount is PERFECT for Chevrolet/GMC Suburban/Tahoe/Silverados 1999 and down.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I made the prototype (this one) with 30% fill and it was really strong, but since there is literally 0.1 mm gap between the walls, I just set it to 100% fill when I made my final version that had my call sign on it.

I set it to 0.2 for 2 reasons; 1st, it's faster. 2nd, it creates a groove feel which actually helps the Baofeng clip to grip onto the unit, and keep it from bouncing out if you are doing some serious off-roading. I've got a big suburban, that's lifted, and gets beat on regularly, things need to stay in place. :)

Rafts are recommended because it's taller than it is wide, but I didn't use any when I built my prototype. Supports aren't needed either, but I like my screw holes to be perfect, so I use them. Again, I didn't use any on my prototype.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
This is San Diego City Robotics watertight end cap for an autonomous underwater vehicle. Included is the .STL files as well as the SolidWorks files. These end caps fit inside a McMaster Carr acrylic 8 inch tube. The O-Ring is a 70 Buna Size 441, which can also be found at McMaster Carr. The epoxy used to fuse the two prints together is https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004RCQ20E/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

BE WARY, This epoxy has toluene in it which will turn ABS into water. Print out this part in PLA if you would like to make this part.

This is an alternative to machining aluminum end caps for a pressurised tube. This solution minimizes the cost of manufacturing end caps for our submarine. SDCR needed a durable enclosure that would hold back water, machining proved to be too expensive so SDCR made these end caps. They take roughly a week to make, and only costs $100 to produce two end caps.

To put this together first coat both parts with epoxy inside and out. Then place part A into part B's corresponding groove. Pour epoxy into part B, the epoxy should drain into part A. After filling both parts with epoxy, use a foam brush to even out the application of epoxy to the outside. Evening of epoxy should happen once every 20 minutes until epoxy holds it's shape. Place the entire setup in a safe place to cure, curing takes 24 hours. After curing is done grease O-Rings with silicon grease and place them in the corresponding grooves. Then coat the entire plug with silicone grease. Make sure to re-apply silicon grease often as it is the key to water tightness.

print_settings.Notes:: Position the case lens side down on the bed, include supports under the font facing curve to ensure a cleaner print. I used 40% infill, this will depend on your printer and how strong or heavy you want the case to be. I wouldn't use a very high infill as this will transfer all the stress on impact directly to the camera.

description.text:
A simple RunCam 2 cover. Typically used with a strap type hold down on a racing or mini quad but it could really be used in any condition the camera needs to be protected. The front of the case extends just slightly beyond the included lens protector. There is no cropping of the image at the corners even with the camera set to the widest FOV. There is no provision for microphone holes, but I did this intentionally to keep wind noise out while flying. You could easily drill a small hole after the print is finished if your audio is too muted. I also didn't design ventilation for the case in general, I will test to see if this causes overheating of the camera.

Update: I have used the camera for several flights in 95 deg. heat with no issue. The covering of the mic holes doesn't work as well as I hoped, I still get wind noise from around the lens. I may perform the resister mod to cut the microphone volume down some.

The buttons, status LED, USB port and rear battery hatch are all fully accessible.

Printer:

SparkLabs SparkCube XL

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.52

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I used Simplify3D to slice.

I like to use PETG to print structural parts for my projects, I've found it to be very durable.

I used a 0.6 size nozzle on my CoreXY based printer.

Position the case lens side down on the bed, include supports under the font facing curve to ensure a cleaner print. I used 40% infill, this will depend on your printer and how strong or heavy you want the case to be. I wouldn't use a very high infill as this will transfer all the stress on impact directly to the camera.

I've uploaded the SketchUp file of the design. It also has the basic mock-up of the Runcam 2 if you want to use it as a template to design your own case. Please feel free to modify the design, just don't start selling the design without giving me a cut :-)

title: Unofficial Thingomatic Heater Board v1.1 r2

description.text:
This is a modified v1.1 Thingomatic Heater Board which has a tab with through-hole pads for soldering and securing the Molex KK 0.156" harness connector as well as the motor connector. This provides a much sturdier mounting point for the wiring connectors, making it much harder to break the connectors off along with their pads. Additionally, this layout has no vias and uses wider traces to the motor connector and to the SMD components. (The heater traces are the same widths and left unchanged other than the removal of the vias.) In the v1.1 r0 version, the connectors are soldered to SMD pads and accidentally bending the Molex connector up or down can leverage its pads right off of the board. While this PCB addresses the mechanical problem with the attachment of the connectors, it does not address the problem associated with overheating of the plastics in the connector shrouds or their mating plugs -- particularly the HEATER- and +12V wires on the wiring harness. To address that problem, instead solder some teflon jacketed wires to the pads (v1.1 r0) or the through holes (v1.1 r2) and then make a pigtail connector or similar. Teflon jacketed wire can take the heat and if you run several inches of it, it should be enough to dissipate the heat before mating with the wiring harness. You can get a small spool of the stuff at a good price in the US from bulkwire.com; the through holes for the Molex connector will easily accommodate 14 gauge wire. Note that the tab is 10.81 mm (0.43") deep and as such will add that much additional length to that side of your heater board. [The tab seen in the pictures is 2.54 mm (0.1") longer than the one in the attached Eagle and Gerber files.] BTW, there is no "r1" that I'm aware of. For whatever reason, I accidentally produced my board with "r2" on it. Cest la vie. A BatchPCB design is available at
http://www.batchpcb.com/product_info.php?products_id=78232&check=38563f546fc5198d95b69e6810006a8e **NOTE: if you are looking for Gerber files for the original Thingomatic Heater Board 1.1, see Thing 16459, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16450

The HEATER11r2.zip file contains the Eagle schematic and board files as well as Gerber files suitable for use with a PCB fab house (e.g., batchpcb.com).   See the enclosed README.TXT file for the files you'd want to send to a fab if you've not done that before.  It will also tell you which Gerber file corresponds to what (top copper, bottom copper, etc.).  Note that the board has an irregular size so this does add to the cost of manufacturing with some fabs.  It's size is also suboptimal for use with Seeed's Fusion PCB service.  For just one or two boards, your best bet is likely batchpcb.com unless you already have a working relationship with some other fab.
When ordering a PCB, be alert to the board's glass transition temperature (Tg).  You don't want a board whose Tg is too close (or below!) the temperature you run your heated platform at.  I used a FR4 with a Tg of 170.  However, you may be okay with 130 or 140C.  (I'm told by a fab that I use that if you keep things to 110C and you trust your temperature measurement, then a Tg of 130C is okay.)
The copper weight should be 1oz.  Making it thicker will only reduce the effectiveness of the heater traces: the thicker the copper, the lower the resistance and thus less heat generated per amp of current.  Some fabs which use a copper deposition process only offer 1.5oz as their lightest copper.  Note that the color of the solder mask usually doesn't have anything to do with rated temperatures.  You can use green if you want.  (Special properties of various solder masks relate to what sort of epoxy and how much is used and how it is applied and cured.)
NOTE: the board pictured here is not exactly what is in the zip file.  After producing a board, I decided to use a different Molex KK connector (the one pictured).  I thus reduced the length of the tab by 2.54mm (0.1") and changed the through hole pads to be offset so that there's a bit more pad to solidly solder the right angle pins of the connector down to.

With the boards in hand, solder in the SMD components. There is a good tutorial on SMD soldering at sparkfun.com, http://www.sparkfun.com/datasheets/Prototyping/General/SolderingBasics.pdf The resistors, capacitor, and thermistor are non-polar: you do not need to worry about their orientation. However, the LED does have a polarity. The arrow/triangle on its bottom should point towards the edge of the PCB (and be on the underside of the LED). Be careful about scratching the topside of the SMD resistors: for a number of chip resistor technologies, the coating on the top of the resistor is the resistive material. Putting it on the bottom of the resistor hinders heat dissipation and, in most applications, chip resistors aren't left where they will come in daily contact with something which might damage them. I've noticed that the official MBI heater boards I've received from MBI have solder added to the two large, unused SMD pads near the thermistor. While that could just be a consequence of the stencil used to apply the solder paste during manufacturing, I've gone ahead and put down some solder on those pads in my build. That on the off chance that they are intended as a heat capacitor/resevoir to smooth out fluctuations in the readings from the thermistor. For the recommended Molex KK connector, you will need to change the orientation of the locking tab. To do so, use some pliers and remove all 6 of the pins. Then re-insert the pins but rotated (around their long axis) by 180 degrees. You want to be able to insert the pins from the bottom side of the board BUT have the locking tab towards the top side of the board. See the third supplied photo for clarification. If you are concerned about the exposed contacts on the top side of the board, then file them down a little and put some Kapton tape over them. Or, if you want some additional overkill in securing the Molex connector, use some JB Weld or other epoxy which can take the heat. Put plenty on the underside and then some on the top side as well over the pads: it'll be just like solder mask which is an epoxy as well. Then, because seeing those contacts may still offend you, put some Kapton tape over them.

For the electronic components, use SMD 1206 size packages. If possible, stick to automotive grade (or better). Automotive grade is meant for hot, nasty environments. Also, I stuck to higher wattage resistors (1/2 W) as they are a bit tougher as regards not derating too fast as the operating temperature rises. However, it's always good to check out the data sheets before buying. Below are some Mouser and (Digikey) part numbers for the components I used. You only need one of each part. Note that if you do not use an ABP, then you can omit the 0,1" pitch pin header -- HDR2 -- which is used to connect the belt motor on the ABP. When ordering, get a flux pen if you don't already own one: fluxing SMD pads before soldering to them is generally a good idea (e.g., Mouser part number 533-0951; a no-clean flux dispensing pen; Digikey presently only carries flux syringes). Finally, if you're inclined to use high temperature solder, then be careful. Some of the high temp solders with silver have melting temperatures at or above 420C -- you can cook your diode and possibly the thermistor as well if you hold them at those temps for too long (measured in seconds). Part - Mouser Part Number (Digikey Part Number) - Description
HDR1 - 538-26-61-5060 or 538-26-64-5060 (WM5239-ND) - Molex KK 0.156" conn., right angle
HDR2 - 571-9-102974-0 (A32704-40-ND) - 0.1" pin hdr, right angle (use 2 of the 40)
R1 - 71-CRCW12064K70JNEAH (541-4.7KUACT-ND) - Resistor, 4.7K 0.5W
R4 - 71-CRCW12061K00JNEAH (541-1.0KUACT-ND) - Resistor, 1.0K 0.5W
R29 - 71-NTHS1206N1N1003JE (541-1145-1-ND) - Thermistor, NTC 100K
C1 - 80-C1206C104K3H (445-2521-1-ND) - Capacitor, ceramic 0.1uF 100V
LED - 645-598-8210-107F (350-2048-1-ND) - LED, red/orange clear An alternative LED -- clear red -- is 160-1457-1-ND. I used the one listed above as I had some on hand.

description.text:
Like most board gamers, we have games that don't come with ways to store and organise the components that come with them. (Well maybe plastic bags, but still those can get daggy/ripped/lost.)

There are a number of people who design and sell these aftermarket items, but I thought I would design and publish one for my most recent addition : Burgle Bros (by Tim Fowers)

So The Burgle Bros game box organiser was born.

Firstly I would like to point out that there might some similarities with other commercial designed organizers for this game, but really - there are only some many logical ways you can store/slot/stack/arrange things that the ergonomics come out pretty similar.

For example, I could have designed a vertical hollow cylinder to store the round tokens used in the game, but then you cant see/count inside such and arrangement, and when you want to get them out, if one get stuck half way down it would be impossible (without a lot of banging of it upside down on the table, and who wants that).

The same thing for storing and arranging tiles. So don't comment/shoot me down for copying someone else's idea.

This design also allows for the manual to be stored in the box like normal, and does not require you to take the insert/space out of the top of the box.

The top tray is designed with a slight angle so that it slides in with issues with the lid/insert. It can still be printed in any orientation as the angle is so small it doesn't require any support.

Both STL (which work) and Openscad for each part is included. This is version 1.1 since the first version I tried (1.0) was to small to fit them in the first time around. (1.1mm to small dang it).

----- Update 25/11/2016 -----
After using the box for the tokens a number of times I release while was good, it had issues.

So I re-designed the box to have a sliding lid and side. a picture is included with the old one (white) and the new box half slide open with tokens inside(transparent PLA).

STL's provided and original openscad if you want to modify it for your printer i.e. the lid(top) tollerence variable. If the lid doesnt fit, increase the tollerence, and just reprint the lid, if the lit has to much slop, decrease the tollerence and reprint the lid.

I designed this one, to fit more tokens of the same size (so not "just enough") so you could use this to store tokens for other games.

New files are called BurgleBros2v0, as SCAD, BOT.stl and TOP.stl.

---------- Update 29/04/2017 -----

Current files you will need to print (older files are there for version/history) are:

BurgleBros_top1.stl x1
BurgleBros1v1.stl x1
BurgleBros2v0_top.stl x1
BurgleBros2v0_bot.stl x1

Printer:

CobbleBot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Note, the bottom tray should be printed on its side, and support for the 2 boxes (used for the sticks in storage[walls in game]) . The reason for this is so that the strata of the print is vertical, thus making it stronger for storing and putting the tiles away.

I printed with eSun white PLA at 205 degree C.
Print time was 12 hours for the base, and 8 hours for the top tray parts.
Speed was 2400mm/min
Sliced with Simplify3d.

Students will be designing their own custom animal with unique adaptations using the app TinkerPlay. Students learn about the different adaptations that animals have in order to survive. This lesson allows students to be creative and combine different types of adaptations in a single animal. Students are able to drag and drop different body parts together in the app to create their new creature. Students must justify why they chose each body part and how it helps their animal to survive.

TinkerPlay is now listed in the app store under the name ThingMaker

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Using the TinkerPlay app (now ThingMaker) on an Apple Device students can drag and drop different body parts to fit their animal. As students choose a body part they can drag it onto the build area. When two body parts get close to one another they create a "lightning" type look showing that they can be connected. Students can add colors and textures to their creation. Once created the STL files can be exported using Google Drive, Dropbox, or other drives. One project will save as multiple STL files. It's easiest to upload all STL files for one student's project into a folder with their name on it for easy printing and organization. Upload the files on to the printing software for the printer of choice and print. Once printed the pieces will snap together like an action figure.
CCSS

Students will be designing their own custom animal with unique adaptations using the app TinkerPlay.  Students need to learn about the different adaptations that animals have in order to survive.  For example, the Fennec Fox adapted to have large ears to radiate body heat and keep them cool in their hot environment.  This lesson allows students to be creative and combine different types of adaptations in a single animal. Students are able to drag and drop different body parts together in the app to create their new creature. After students create their new animal they can continue to create a habitat for their animal which further demonstrates their knowledge of the adaptations they’ve created.  (ie: if they create an animal with big ears like the fennec fox then they would create a desert environment for the animal to live, showing that they understand that the ears help the animal stay cool).  Students can also complete a language arts lesson with their animal by writing a story about how the animal came to be, or justifying the different adaptations the animal has.  Students can also write about a day in the life of their unique animal and explain how it’s adaptations help the animal to survive and thrive.

The student will learn about different animal adaptations.  The students will create their own animal and justify their choices in adaptations by explaining how it helps their animal to survive.  The student will understand the basics of 3D printing and design.

-Virginia SOL: SCI5.1b: The student will investigate and understand that animals, including people, have life needs and specific physical characteristics and can be classified according to certain characteristics. Key concepts include:
b) physical characteristics (body coverings, body shape, appendages, and methods of movement)
  • Common Core: Common Core 3rd Grade: https://www.weteachnyc.org/media/filer_public/9a/81/9a811f64-85b6-4b56-b130-133907b47209/g3_science_animal_adaptations.pdf
    Animal Adaptations Science CCSS: http://www.isbe.net/profprep/CASCDvr/Wd97/27140_sciencecore.doc

• Download the TinkerPlay (ThingMaker) app onto student iPads

  • Introduce lesson after students have some background knowledge on different adaptations

  • Explain to students that they will get to create their own unique animal. Students will need to think carefully about their body part choices to make sure their animal will be best suited for “survival” in the wild.

  • Demonstrate to students how to drag and drop each body part onto the workspace to create the animal.

  • As body parts get close to each other they will start producing a “lightning” effect showing that they can be connected together.

  • Each student (or groups of students) get an iPad to start creating.

  • When students feel that they are finished they need to check with a teacher and explain each body part of the animal. Students must be able to justify each part of their animal and explain how they help their animal to survive.

  • Once the teacher has checked the student’s work the teacher can export the STL. files to either a Dropbox account or Google Drive within the app.

  • One animal may consist of multiple STL. files to complete one print. Make sure that teachers save the files in a folder under the student’s name for easy printing and organization.

  • Arrange the STL. files on the 3D printing software of choice and print. (It will save time to print multiple student's designs on the build plate at once. 2-3 seemed to work best)

  • Once the pieces are printed remove them from their base and snap them together to make the animal figures.
    • It will save time to print 2-3 student's designs on a build plate at a time. It will save time to print 2-3 student's designs on a build plate at a time. This is a graded assignment from a first grade student explaining her work and the animal she created.

In order to complete this lesson teachers need an iPad with TinkerPlay (now ThingMaker) app uploaded.  Teachers also need a dropbox or google drive account to upload completed creations. Finally teachers need a 3D Printer to print student's design.

This project can take as little as one lesson or can be stretched throughout an entire unit.  Teachers can choose to do this lesson as a standalone project or create an entire unit around it.  Students can create a habitat for their print as well as writings describing how they live and how their adaptations work
Students should know about some animal adaptations background knowledge and understand how physical adaptations help certain animals survive in their habitats.

Students should have their completed animal by the end of this project. Teachers should grade students by their knowledge and ability to justify how the adaptations they chose for the animal will help their animal survive. Teachers can also grade on whether or not students can identify a habitat in which their animal would best fit.  Please see the PDF for the grading sheet we used with our students.

The following video shows a quick preview how to use the TinkerPlay app and some of the different additions that can be used when using TinkerPlay. This is how the STL files look when all added onto the printer. What the app TinkerPlay looks like.

title: 3D Printed Slimes [Slime Rancher] - Boom, Phosphor, Rad & Honey!

description.text:
If you'd like to see more information and how I made these, you can watch this video: https://youtu.be/9C4ALG_iby4

Adding to my 3D printed slime collection this time is the Honey Slime, Phosphor Slime, Rad Slime and the explosive Boom Slime. I created all of these in Fusion 360 using the same template I created in the first video to make life easier on myself.

Link to Fusion 360: http://autode.sk/1s0ABZA

After I finished modeling I prepared the models in Simplify3D and printed them out on my Robo3D R1 using Hatchbox PLA. Not sponsored or anything, just listing what I use. :)

Then my wife painted these slimes using a combination of primer, airbrush and brush paints. I would tell you the colors but she mixes all of her own colors so that would be sort of difficult to describe and document.

I'm really happy with how these came out. Let me know what you think and if you'd like to see any other combinations of these slimes. Like a Tabby Slime with a drooling mouth. Anything like that.

Print Settings:
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Infill: 20%
Supports: Yes on the Phosphor Slime, no on the rest
Raft: No

Every week or so, I will drop a few off at his house, and he's convinced they're popping out of the ground like in the game.
I'm currently working on a set of Boom slimes, but having a hard time painting the small cracks. I'm trying to use a toothpick, but it's messy going. Any suggestions?

description.text: Prior to this lesson, students will be engaged in a unit of study around lines and angles. This lesson introduces two pieces of technology (Google Draw and Tinkercad) to demonstrate learning about lines and angles.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Students will be creating their own keychain design that demonstrates their understanding of lines and angles using Google Draw.
Students will be using Tinkercad to incorporate their Google Draw design into a keychain design.

Lesson Overview Approximately 10 minutes
Duration of Lesson: 1 week
Understanding the Lesson video Materials
  • Tinkercad
  • Google Draw
  • PLA
    • Lesson Part 1: Designing on Google Draw Share the overview and challenge of the project. Start the lesson by introducing students to Google Draw. Students can directly design on Google Draw or draw the design on paper. Lesson Part 2: Converting Google Draw to .SVG Google Draw does not always export correctly to .svg so we exported as .jpg and used a converter. Tinkercad allows the import of either an .svg or .stl file. An .svg file can be a converted .jpg or .png file. I use the following .svg converter - http://picsvg.com/ An .stl file is any file that has been created for 3D printing. This import ability allows the designer to import any 3D design and rework it or build upon it. In this project, you can use the .stl to build the final pieces. Lesson Part 3: Creating the Keychain in Tinkercad Students will need to create a base for their design which includes a hole or the incorporation of a ring attached to the base. Design choices like raised or receding will also be an option. This is a good time to talk about millimeters as Tinkercad and 3D printing are normally designed in the metric system. It is essential to help students to understand what would be the appropriate sizing of a keychain. Lesson Part 4: Printing Students will need to export the design for 3D printing from Tinkercad as an .stl file and share it with the teacher for final printing. Printing will take approximately 30 minutes per design.
    Rafts: no
    Supports: no
    Resolution: 0.2 mm
    Infill: 10%

• Google Draw. Modifications: Use- MakerBot PrintShop or Morphi
  • Tinkercad

Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.4.G.A.1 - Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.

3D printed nails appear to be a terrible idea. I figured they would be, but I wanted to try it anyway, so I gave it my best shot. This design places the nails horizontally to avoid delamination issues. 100% infill is necessary to have any chance at the necessary rigidity.

After testing and smashing of pieces, I can discern no obvious utility of this, and do not recommend using it for anything. But I figured I'd upload it anyway because I couldn't find anyone else who had, and there seem to be many tinkerers here who might enjoy experimenting with this anyway. Perhaps there is a material out there which makes this useful, but PLA does not appear to be it.

This works in Customizer. Good luck!
Watch your fingers.

comments.text: may not be totally useless, plastic nails are used to anchor objects on a board, say for cnc routing, and then you tap the side to break the nail and remove the cut material. For this use, print direction might be important.

comments.text: Rather than splintering, in my tests the usual failure mode involved it snapping with the break line directly across the short axes, even after reinforcing this direction by printing horizontally.  Also, printing horizontally yielded a much sharper tip for me, with that last part probably being at least partly due to Cura's methodology.  But there is certainly plenty of room for trying different approaches to this.

This is a simple Coral Reef Frag Plug for your salt water aquarium. It fits perfectly in an egg crate slot. It has a small hole in the top for holding glue. It weighs about 1/8 of an once using PLA at 100% fill. It sinks!

We discovered there are 2 sizes of egg crate. Ones with 14mm wide and 13mm wide holes. So, be sure to download the right file for your egg crate. You can also scale it of course but the 13mm and 14mm versions have the same head size. Print it out, cut off a piece of your coral, glue it to the plug and insert it into an empty slot in your egg crate. Super easy, super cheap! You can now also download it in a 12 pack! Also, be sure to check out Shane's frag plug http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16982

comments.text: Are PLA and/or ABS reef safe? I build my own tanks/filter systems, mostly because I do nano and pico systems, but I've always used laser-cut acrylic because I've been afraid of destroying water quality.
comments.author: rocketmannate

comments.text: Great question. The short answer is yes, ABS and PLA are safe however, I don't know if the colorant is safe. PLA resin is clear and if it's high quality PLA, it's pure poly-lactic-acid which is derived from corn starch. This makes it a some-what natural product. I've known people who used PLA in their reef aquariums and the parts didn't degrade over the course of months and it didn't affect the condition of the water. It may degrade over the course of years. I'm confident that natural color, pure PLA is safe. In order to get colors, you have to add a colorant and I've had trouble finding information on this. If you're reading this and you know what they put in the colorant, leave a comment. In the mean time, use high quality, USA made, natural PLA. Also note that PLA floats. ABS is likely already in your tank. Pumps, pipes and other equipment are made with ABS some times. Again though, I'd only use high quality ABS without colorant unless you know more about what colorant was used. You can't have red legos with ABS alone, something has to be added to make it red. One last thing, to be totally clear, we are talking about pure PLA and pure ABS. It wouldn't surprise me if there are manufacturers in the world who are not using pure products. I would trust NatureWorks. Good luck!

description.text:
This is a snap-fitting enclosure for the PINE64, the famous $15 64bit computer funded on Kickstarter in 2015. It's designed to offer something unique and exciting to complement the computer, and of course take advantage of 3D printing. You can access all of the ports and features with the enclosure fitted, or the snap fits allow you to very quickly pop it open without needing any tools. Great spot on top to store SD cards, USB sticks etc.

The bottom part is best printed with the base on your print plate (I printed with a brim), and the top part is best printed upside down, with the top laying flat on the plate. Only a small amount of support material is needed for the center section

This design was used as a tutorial I wrote for a Formlabs article called "How to Design 3D Printed Snap Fit Enclosures." Head to my blog for all the details https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/2016/07/30/design-a-3d-printed-snap-fit-enclosure/

author: MAXANJLI

description.text:
The Crossbow Helper Kit is now depreciated. Please see my new project for a full 3D printable crossbow called TALC. The project is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:187718 Please use proper safey equipment before using any of these parts and check local laws. Most of these parts have not been properly tested. Although I have printed a few of them off. It is your responsibility to ensure the safety of the parts you build. I am attempting to create a crossbow that can be created solely on a 3D printer. The purpose of the crossbow is for backyard fun only. In other words, simple target shooting. I am releasing this kit to aid others who are creating a wooden/metal/other materials homemade crossbow. Such as the designs you will find on The SlingShot Channel: http://www.slingshotchannel.com/. This is not a universal crossbow kit. It is just parts from my project. Such parts that you may or may not find useful. What is this kit? TALC Kit: Lite Edition TALC stands for TActical printabLe Crossbow kit. This is not a full crossbow kit. This is an aid kit only to help in the construction of a crossbow. That's why it is called lite edition. Some of the parts may not be useful for your project but you may find something. All parts were drawn using FreeCad. Which is a free application. http://www.freecadweb.org/ What is included in this kit? I have included all stl, step and fcstd files for each part. So feel free to modify them. If you do decide to use some of my parts in your design, please credit appropriately. All parts are released under the GNU GPL License. Crossbow Parts Include:
-Stock and stock extension
-Tactical Foregrip
-Simple Trigger
-Moveable Bipod Stand
-Tactical Rail System
-Handle
-Simple Sight
-Untested but I have also created a mockup of the roller system (platform and rollers) used in the Strong Bullpup Slingshot Crossbow designed by JoergSprave from The SlingShot Channel. I will update and add more parts as I finish them. Cheers;
Anthony
Parts like the stock or handle can be printed at 0.25 layer height. I recommend using support material if available.

Still developing, but so far I've got the push button prototype working great. The one issue that I've seen with the Mantis Claw is that it really wants to hold on, but not let go.

This remix modifies the top plate, the top arms, and adds a button in order to allow the mantis claw to release what ever it has grabbed. They modified parts are identified by the blue pieces in the photo. This could potentially be pushed by a small actuator electronically.

Check out the video of the button in action here.

To Do:

  • rework to allow for mounting of a string.
  • rework to connect the bottom and top plates since the button takes the place of the center bolt.

comments.text: I've added an image to this thing that hopefully shows how it works.  Basically print all the parts from the original mantis claw this was remixed from, with the exception of the 5 top arms and only print one base.  Then print 5 of the arms, one button, and one top plate from this thing.  Follow the assembly instructions from the original, but slide the button through the hole of the top plate prior to pushing it into place over the joints and the extended top arms.

title: Tweaker5 XT60 + SMA Antenna Mount + Piezo Buzzer Mount for KK2 KK2.1

description.text:
Tweaker5 220mm : XT60 + SMA Antenna Mount + Piezo Buzzer Mount for KK2 KK2.1
by jbleazie & Figles, published July 29, 2016

*Second and third versions added.

Inspired by Arakon & nickroosen concept.
The Original design was for the Tweaker 180mm frame.

Mounts to the rear standoffs of an Andy Shen "Tweaker5" 220mm frame.
http://shendrones.myshopify.com/collections/frames/products/tweaker-5-pre-order
I really liked this concept, but it was only available for the smaller frame. My friend aka "Figles" helped modify the original design by Arakon & nickroosen. I kept breaking the SMA connector vertically mounted to the frame, so we added an angled antenna mount to hopefully minimize the strain on the connector. You can use an SMA Male to SMA Female RG316 Extension Cable.
https://www.fpvheadquarters.com/fpv/accessories/sma-accessories.html

Piezo Buzzer mount Dimensions (Buzzer): 9 x 11.8mm
There is also space on the rectangular rear plate allowing you to mount a short LED strip.

Tweaker 180 XT60 + Antenna Mount + Buzzer Mount
by nickroosen, published May 18, 2016

Remix of Arakon's mount. Added a holder for a 12mm buzzer. I wanted to stop hot-gluing mine to the side of the mount. Used TPU for added flexibility, as I've now broken two after impacts. The TPU also allows for some compression on the pigtail so my antenna is no longer wobbly.

Tweaker 180 XT60 + Antenna mount
by Arakon, published Nov 29, 2015

Update:
V2 added. Strengthened the antenna area some and closed it off entirely (no open side anymore).

Mounts to the rear of the Tweaker.
All components should fit easily, for the XT60, apply a drop of CA glue on all four sides before pushing it in.
Meant for use with an angled antenna mount such as http://www.surveilzone.com/5cm-sma-plug-to-right-angle-sma-jack-cable-pa1216
VTX then mounts underneath the top plate of the tweaker.

Rectangular rear plate allows you to stick a short LED strip to it.

description.text:
My well used dremel tool stopped working and after taking it apart I found that the flexible rubber coupler between the motor and the output shaft had disintegrated. I took some rough measurements with some calipers designed a replacement.

This is the first thing I have printed with flexible filament and the the splines didn't come out well with a lot of detail, but it went together and seems to do the job.

title: Mountable peristaltic gear pump, comes with allen key

description.text:
Water was escaping from the tube before for my prints despite different sizes of my tubes.
Took the original Drmn4ea's pump and added an extra hole at the top for the tube, to allow more gears to engage at any given time.
Custom added in a mount similar to Stonege's mount.

Included a working 1/4 inch allen key as well.

Have fun!

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

any

Notes:

I printed with PLA using Up plus 2,
worked with 0.15mm,
chose least dense but do use infills,
normal detail, no raft no support.

everything else was left as default ( 3 layers for parts.)

comments.text: the are positive displacement pumps that move a constant volume per cycle. The limit to volumetric flow rate is the revolutions per minute. They do have low flow rates for comparable power input of other impeller type pumps and they are prone to wear out more quickly, given the pressures and frictional forces.  Ideal use is to pump liquids to hire elevations and flow rate is not a factor.

Sometimes you need to take off or land somewhere that just isn't flat, solid, or safe enough for your Inspire 1. Hand launching and hand catching is possible on the stock aircraft but difficult and not terribly safe.

This is meant to solve all that by giving you a solid handle to grasp. It's very strong and very light, and you can easily handle the craft. Simply hold in mid-air, start the props, and off you go!

The VPS occasionally thinks the handle is the ground and aborts raising the landing gear, but simply repeating the process should work and, if you have the automatic landing gear off, should not recur during flight.

comments.text: the aspire is quite big as are the props for it. imho the props are what makes it unsafe to catch not the landing gear really. example if it had a issue gsp or any it is so big to control with only one hand. i have done this with bigger ones also but i would warn against as i had no real control it went crazy one esc was going bad not bad yet it still turned the motor but was feeding the wrong rates.

description.text:
This thing is a 8x5cm nameplate / doorplate.

The FreeCAD source file is included.

If you need help on how to create 3D Text in FreeCAD read this tutorial.

It should be easy to create a sign with not intersecting fonts.

The example file "Maison Edith" shows a font where the single letters intersect each other. This can cause problems in FeeCAD if you try boolean tools (e.g. boolean cut to create engraved text). I was not able to solve this problem. Of course you can always try to have a boolean cut for each letter (letter by letter) to circumvent this problem.

Instead I created an extruded text string, placed it on top of the plate and created a compund instead of performing a boolean join. After exporting the STL I ran the file through netfabb to generate a printable file.

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula prusa i3

No

No

0.2

40%

Notes:

The smaller the nozzle, the better the result (especially if you choose fonts with thin lines).
Try different slicers if you see gaps in the top fill or parts of the text are missing.

remixed_from.author: sgraber
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Laser Cut Frame and Braces

description.text:
A modified version of the Mendel90 which uses a lasercut melamine coated MDF frame (same fixing idea as the graber i3 frame). It allows an acrylic enclosure to be fitted. Main changes: Frame re-designed, Z axis changed to laser cut parts.
Some plastic parts modified (not many)
Acrylic enclosure added
Wiring simplified - all motors have detachable plugs, endstops are push fit. this allows for a wiring loom to be used.
RAMPS electronics as standard with the Panelolu2 controller. All the detail is available on our blog:
http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2013/09/mendel90-laser-cut-ready-to-print.html The assembly process in more detail in in this post: http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2013/10/mendel90-lasercut-overview.html The commissioning and calibration in outline is here:
http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2013/10/mendel90-lasercut-calibration.html The printer is designed from the start to take multiple bowden extruders as an alternative to a single direct drive extruder. Updates will follow!

The assembly and calibration process is outlined on the blog http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2013/10/mendel90-lasercut-overview.html http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2013/10/mendel90-lasercut-calibration.html The up to date source files are available from github:
https://github.com/T3P3/Mendel90/tree/LaserCut
Including the full assembly instructions.:
https://github.com/T3P3/Mendel90/tree/LaserCut/lasercut/manual

description.text:
Parametric hinged and bolted attachment for square bars This OpenSCAD script will generate a 2 part holder to attach a Tyndall WIMUv3 to the upright square cross-sectional posts on the moveable sled part of the assassin trainer at Bath University. The size of the bar it is attached to can be parametrically varied Version: 0.9
Date: 2012-05-31 Todo:
  • clean up code to make more parametric
  • test fit and adjust
  • add "wiggle" for bolts and captured nuts
  • add option to choose orientation of WIMU holder section
  • add optional corner fins to prevent thermal stress cracks when printing in black ABS
    • Warnings:
    None Note:
    You will need to also have the modules mouse_ears_test.scad, pivot_1_0.scad and rounded_cuboid_v2.4.scad in the same directory or your library for this to compile correctly Changes from previous versions:
    0.9
  • added option to choose position of hinge/bolt holes along sides
  • added second captive nut section on side for tightening holder to bar
    0.8
  • added tolerancing for bar fit
  • added second bolt pivot
    0.7
  • added padding partial cutout between Z axis of wimu and front/top face of wimu holder
  • added variable for and increased pivot size around hinge pin to 5
  • added extra mouse ears under wimu holder in attempt to prvent it from curling etc.
  • increased height of wimu by 0.8 mm as previously printed item despite having a nominal .stl measured height of 31.4 it measured only 30.2 when printed also note average height of 5 wimus measured was 31mm
    0.6
  • increased size of side holes to allow for viewing of status LEDs
  • changed the size of cutouts on WIMU holder section to help with removal of WIMU
  • added cutout under WIMU holder to help with removal of WIMU
  • added captive nut section for tightening holder to bar
    0.5
  • added WIMU packaging to check location of cutouts
    0.4
  • Adjusted position of cutouts around hinge and bolt clamp so that they dont go all the way through the wall to make for easier printing and drilling
  • Made hinge pin larger to make it easier to insert hinge pin without drilling
    0.3
  • Added option to add device holder on side or not using use_holder variable
  • Fixed large clamp part so that it has correct internal dimensions
  • Increased height of small cutouts on long side of WIMU hodler so that activity LED can be seen
  • added comments
  • Moved everything up onto the build plane
  • Fixed some translate issues where bar_stock_l and bar_stock_b were mixed up
  • Moved the hinge and bolt side cutouts so that a thin piece of material would connect the 2 halves
  • Moved the mouse ears into the union and differecne operations applied to the main clamp body
    0.2
  • reduced individual parts count by using the pivot module only twice and using cut lines to split it up
    0.1
  • First attempt

• Measure the bar stock of the item you want to attach this to and the XYZ dimensions of the item you want to attach to it and alter script varaibles to match.

  • Print and cleanup
  • Assemble 2 halves using suitably sized nuts and bolts &/or plastic filament for catch and hinge
  • insert appropriately sized electronic device into cavity
  • Attach to item to be instrumented by wrapping the 2 hinged halves around the square bar stock
  • Bolt tightly in place
  • Do some science!
  • ???
  • Profit!

description.text:
I have a tripod head that has a limited vertical range of motion, so I designed this 45 degree wedge to allow me to get greater elevation angles on my camera when needed.

Additional parts used:

  • 1/4-20 brass heat set inserts for plastics (i.e. McMaster-Carr part no. 93365A162)
  • 1/4-20 x 1.00" button head socket cap screw (i.e. McMaster-Carr part no. 98164A214)
  • Adhesive cork sheeting (sold at arts and crafts stores for lining cabinet bottoms)
  • A strong epoxy, i.e. JB Weld or Devcon for securing the screw in the thumbscrew housing.

Tools used:

  • Soldering iron (for installing the threaded insert)
  • Supplies for mixing and applying the epoxy, i.e. aluminum foil for mixing on, toothpicks for stirring and applying, gloves, safety goggles, etc.
  • Craft knife and scissors for cutting up the cork liner and cleaning up the printed part as needed.

Notes:

  • This design uses a captive thumbscrew. Make sure the thumbscrew and screw are installed in the body BEFORE you epoxy the thumbscrew and screw together. There is no way to insert or remove it after the two parts are epoxied together.
  • Make sure to get the brass threaded insert installed straight. My strategy for this is to use a low temperature so the insert flows into the hole very slowly, then when it has reached a level slightly deeper than flush with the surface, I quickly remove the iron and put a 1/4-20 screw in a few turns and have a look from a few different angles to see if it's straight enough. If it needs straightening, remove the screw, warm the insert back up with the soldering iron and adjust as needed. I then use a craft knife to clean up the hardened ABS ooze around the insert. There should be a little ooze lip, otherwise your hole was too loose for the insert and it may not be securely mounted. This may vary with your printer's performance, all the tolerances in this design are based on my personal experience with my own printer.
  • I included both STL and STEP files in case you want to make changes; I know that for me importing and editing STL files is very problematic and STEP files are much preferred.

Disclaimer:

As with anything else supporting your expensive camera equipment, test, test, test, until YOU are satisfied that it's strong enough. You are using this design at your own risk, and I am not responsible for any damages or injury that results.

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci

Rafts:

No

Yes

100%

Notes:

My printer is a modified XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 -- PEI sheet over a borosilicate bed, using my own E3D V6 Bowden conversion (another one of my Things).

I suggest printing this with the camera-side down (the side with the cork applied in my photos). The only support necessary should be for the overhang that keeps the thumbscrew captive. Because this area is not really visible when it's assembled, you don't have to worry too much about getting rid of the support interface marks on the part, just make sure it's smooth so the thumbscrew doesn't drag on it.

I used ABS plastic and I would absolutely print this with a solid infill.

Some detailed part addons for the cool Oblivion Defender Drone by BrandonW6
  • Detailed Thrusters for primary secondary rockets (Still fits stand)
  • Auxiliary thruster addons (Print same colour as body)
  • Spring loaded strut to allow gun mounts to rotate.
    • I wanted the guns to be rotatable so I simply hold them in place with a cross spar and spring (or rubber band) from one strut to the other to hold the gun mounts in place. This allows you to rotate them. You could use any piece of plastic the right length for this if you want. I have included a picture to show what I mean.

A couple of years ago I remixed the Mini Quadruped parts to fit some cheap servos I had purchased from Amazon. I really appreciated TheCase including the OpenSCAD files since that was my first reason to play with OpenSCAD and now I love it.

The file I'm posting here is a beginners build of a piece to hold a breadboard. I used it to mount a Arduino Mini on it and make other servo/sensor connections.

I never really felt like I had finished it but will post it since someone was recently looking for a small platform.

author: SavageWarlord

description.text: This helps you to achieve a quick and easy level of the build bed. Ignore the stl file for the cap. It is a place holder only.

I have printed my share of brackets and things to hold a dial gauge and other measurement tools to get my printer's build bed perfectly level. They are all a pain as far as I'm concerned. So finally this was born.  
Take 3 pieces of adhesive copper tape and locate them on the build platform as shown in the picture. Right above the levelling screws. Solder a wire that connects al three and leave a fair amount of wire from the last patch.   
Take another piece of hookup wire strip a bout 5 cm of the end and ind this bare copper wire around the hotend. Take your multimeter and connect the two probes to the two wires. If yours will beep when continuity is detected all that much better.  
Now comes the fun part. Make sure the nozzle is clean, otherwise take some aceton and wipe it clean. Now move the printhead above the center adjustment screw and lower it to z=0 (home) adjust the bed levelling screw until the beep goes away or if you measure an open lead. Do the same with the other two points, then check the first one again. I do this with everything cold, to get a rough level, then I heat everything up to working temperatures and do it once more. Eh, voila you'll have a perfectly level bed in a simple manner.  
Of course you could rig up an LED and circuit to do the same thing but this worked quick and dirty. You could use a throwee and use it to do the same.  
Have fun.

comments.text: Great idea foolproof, simple, cheap and easy.
comments.author: Mcoltas

comments.text: Attaching a temporary strut to the hot end mount with a cheap microswitch at the tip would be a lot more accurate and simpler to implement. There may be variations with the depth of each of the three pieces of copper tape. The microswitch will also allow you to take more samples at different positions on the print bed just in case your print bed is slightly warped.
comments.author: Tony3D

comments.text: No you miss my point, there you go and print another bracket. You now need to make sure the switch is at the same height as the printhead. That is a pain to say the least. The tape has a very thin and almost perfectly repeatable thickness. You print on glass that is perfectly flat, you only need 3 points to make it level. Rest is overkill.
comments.author: Tony3D

comments.text: It is easier to separate the bed levelling task from that of z axis homing. For bed levelling the microswitch is positioned lower than that of the print heads so that the print head nozzle does not interfere with the bed levelling calibration. Even the smallest amount of ooze or swarf from one of the print nozzles will ruin your calibration. Also a print nozzle may not be perfectly perpendicular to the bed. It would be very difficult to perfectly level the nozzle.  With use glass may inperceptably warp hence taking multiple samples can save you money by reducing failed prints or identify some areas on the print bed where parts my not stick properly. Glass is not always perfectly level. Your photo highlights the visible dimples in the copper tape - they are caused by small changes in height which will impact your calibration. This will add measurement errors on top of errors. The effort you put into calibration really depends on what you plan to print and the quality that you desire.
comments.author: janbeckman

comments.text: That's good for PLA, but for ABS, you're typically not using glass.
comments.author: janbeckman

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1702184

This is the P-Aimer

After testing some Smartphones with my first Aimer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1694981), I decided to make it more simple to use as much mobiles as I can. This Aimer should work for any smart phone between 7 and 10 mm thickness and above.

To print it on the side (more stable ring-clip), I had to remove the outer ring of the display part.

Tested with:
Sony Xperia Z
Samsung Galaxy S6
Iphone 6S

I will update the devices as soon as tested. You can use the ring at the back side for your little finger, so you can catch the Pokemon one-handed (pro style :D)

I wanted to change the settings for the thickness of my desk so it hugged it nicely. I copied the design into openscad so that I can make this for the different thicknesses that I need to deal with.

If your desk thickness is not 25mm, modify the openscad file with the value

desk_thickness = 25;

to your desk thickness and exporting it as STL for consumption by your slicer.

I found it best to print one, check it fits, then create out as many you need on a single print.

You could also no modify the thickness and tape it to the bottom of the desk with doublesided tape. This may be an easier option for those who don't want ot use openscad.

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Using openscad

I imported the previous stl object from mattlang and then created the openscad objects to match the dimensions as best as I could.

Designed over the top, once done, moved the values out into parameters. And the result you see here.

title: FrightProps.com Standard Speed Linear Actuators SKU: 1002-SSLA

description.text:
I have created a ball and socket to attach to a Standard Speed Linear Actuators
SKU: 1002-SSLA available from Frightprops.com.

http://www.frightprops.com/electric-motors/linear-actuators/linear-actuators-assemblies/standard-speed-linear-actuators.html

This was made for a seance table prop. All said and done it will levitate the table from the bottom middle, and give the appearance of a floating table.

The ball has a 20mm - 0.79" hole, and can attach to either end of the actuator. I also has a 6mm hole for securing.

Travel is about 12 degrees in any direction.

Ball:
49mm
20mmD x 17mm deep hole

Socket:
mounting flange- 86mm x 86 mm x 10 mm
Ball socket- 62mm x 62mm x 40mm
Overall height - 50mm

Light sanding (120 grit) was required to smooth out the assembled operation.
Total print time- both pieces - approx 4 hours on LOW

I have added a video of the final build... SHHH.... don't tell anyone about this...its for this years haunt! https://youtu.be/nsLshJ9G50M

description.text:
Have an iPad or iPad 2? Or perhaps a tablet PC that you love to carry around but lack the hardware to keep it upright when surfing the web or reading an e-book? Look no further! This elegantly designed tablet stand is the ideal solution.
The simplicity of its design gains inspiration from three identically-sized spheres that encircle a central sphere to produce a sturdy stand. The material is made out of durable ivory-gloss polyurethane with soft rubber protrusions that act as "grips" to keep your iPad or tablet PC in place.
The set comes with two sphericals that can be positioned anywhere on the tablet's base in either the vertical or horizontal position, whichever best suites your needs.

Be sure to print two pieces since they come in a pair. The rubberized grips are available if ordered through my ponoko website at: http://www.ponoko.com/design-your-own/products/sphericals-2-0-ipad-stand-6780 Enjoy! =)

Created this remix to be able to stack droolops together to create a multiple color flower without dual extrusion. Print each in different colors and then insert one into the other with a dab of glue or ABS slurry to hold them together.

It's hard to tell the difference in colors from the photos because the two filaments I had on hand (dark purple and dark blue) are very close to the same hue.

  • Update 08/03/2016: Added beziervase remix to have 3 stacked flowers mounted in the vase on the end of 3mm filament. Photo shows printed in Gizmo Dorks Wood Filament (my first non-cube print with wood).

comments.text: For whatever reason, I just cannot get the smaller layer to print without getting stuck to the nozzle. However, the larger layer prints perfectly! I am making them in a bunch of different colors. Nice work. I am looking forward to trying out the vase as well!
comments.author: WeGotA3DPrinter

comments.text: You may try slicing with a brim so that it has a little more surface area to put down on the first layer.  Bed adhesion is critical for these because of the minimal contact between the part and the bed.  I've used several different options for that, but heated bed with PEI sheet adhered to glass with 3m double sided heat resistant tape has worked best for me for first layer bed adhesion. Temperature of bed of course depends on material, but typically I print PLA at 60C - 70C and ABS at 100C - 110C.

This is a concept that I came up with when I wanted to design my own bookmark. I'm an avid reader and resorted to using Post-It notes to bookmark my novels and textbooks. After a while I realized that it was a very practical approach, but not at all aesthetically pleasing to the eye. So given my innate desire to design and create, I knew that the only sensible thing to do was to design my own product, one that could not be purchased at a bookstore or ordered online. I wanted authenticity.
It had to be functional yet elegant, simple yet creative. And after some initial design sketches, I finally came up with the Tree Origins bookmark. As seen in the item picture, it is designed to resemble a tree in an abstract way. Although seemingly organic in its shape, the geometry is actually quite symmetrical. The disparate nature of its design is what makes the idea work.
I produce this bookmark using a flexible and resilient high-gloss PVC plastic material.The flexible property enables it to easily 'squeeze' pages together to produce a firm hold.
If you like the design, please spread the love =)
Be careful to not bend the tree branches since they tend to be quite thin.

author: doug_melville

description.text:
I really like ClericAaron's dice tower with the swappable trays, but it was just a touch too tall (145mm) for my Dreamer (Z 140mm.) Also, it's a long build and I needed it for a gift the next day; couldn't afford to get ten hours in and have something go wrong. (What? What could possibly go wrong when 3D printing???)

I used OpenSCAD to slice the main tower into four smaller parts. To assist with assembly, there are peg holes for aligning each section. The holes are 10mm height and 5mm diameter; just print some slightly smaller pegs to put this together, apply a bit of epoxy...or, drop a couple of magnets in one piece and metal BBs in the opposite.

The bottom opening is sliced about halfway through, so I took out ClericAaron's custom support. The second piece, the arch, is now pretty low to the print bed and printed just fine with support in Simplify3D.

Nothing too fancy; ClericAaron did all the hard design work. To make it into separate printable pieces I:

  1. Imported to OpenSCAD.
  2. Created four modules, one for each piece.
  3. Used difference() and some cubes to section out each piece.
  4. Voided a couple of cylinders straddling the line between each pair of pieces for peg holes.

comments.text: This printed well for my MP Mini V2.  I am going to try the split tray from ClericAaron next, since the full trays are too big,  Ill post pics when I finish assembly.

description.text:
for those who want a heated bed but lack the facilities to do so without modification on their current printer setup (eg- printrite 3d diy printer users)

this design is originally made to give me a second heated bed surface that I can use to Acetone Vaper treat ABS parts away from the actual printers heatbed (alot safer than doing it on the printer HB as I can move the whole setup to somewhere with zero flame sources and better ventilation)

Alternatively as mentioned, the setup can be used to add a heatbed to a non heatbed equipped printer.

The heatbed itself is controlled via a W1209 thermostatic controller board which is capable of taking the HB upto 110°c (ABS levels etc) and is incredibly simple to wire and operate, in addition the controller supplies all required power to the HB from its own power source (a low spec ATX PSU will suffice aslong as it can supply 12amp+) so in the case of the Printrite theres no need for upgrading the power supply or messing with any of the interior connections (which given how delicate the mainboard is in a PR, is a definate bonus)

the controller itself can be happily positioned where ever you chose but you must bare in mind that the printers software will have no control over the heatbed atall and you must manually set temps and turn off & on.

The design for the controller housing is not my own but taken from a design I came across on tinkercad, I forget the designers name but it can be easily found on that site so any credit for the design is entirely his own (I never use others designs typically but his has proven an excellent fit and credit were credits due)

the controller Ive used:-
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/182000470910?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Its advisable to use the thermistor its supplied with as the board doesnt seem to like the standard versions used on heatbeds (the uncovered 100k ntc versions), the thermistor capsule can be simply taped to the back of the heatbed and supplies surprisingly accurate readings (measured with both a thermistor running from my Ramps setup aswell as a lazer thermometer)

Printer:

colido printrite diy ramps1.4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

30%

Notes:

oh before I forget.......... parts must be made from ABS, dont try PLA for obvious reason, as soon as you try to set the bed to ABS adhesion levels the PLA will soften and thats bye bye bed level

Designed from my Da Vinci Pro when I was disassembling it.
I saw some guys cutting the original one to make some mod and that hurt me... lol...
You can use it to do whatever modification you want.

bonsai_motor_mount:
Here, a new motor mount for any 22 diameter brushless motor. It breaks easily, going to improve it...

bonsai_mount_v4:
I built a new Bonsai using an Emax 1306 Motor. The mount v4 file fits this motor. Pictures attached. It is much more stable this time. Pinted it with 4 perimeter shells and 50% infill. With the 2205 Motors i had problems getting the CG right. This ist why i'm using the lighter 4000kv 1306 motor with 2-3S at 4" Prop (without cutting the wing).

comments.text: I love the v4 attachment method, but I really need the larger mounting holes since I run a 2008 motor, and it's been perfectly balanced for a while now.
comments.author: OPEC

comments.text: Great mount, but the legs snapped off during the 2nd landing (not a hard one)... You may want to reinforce them by making them thicker at the point where they meet the mount.
comments.author: lexyp

comments.text: Hi, you're very right. Mine broke too. Maybe i should go over it one more time. Thanks for your input :)
comments.author: lexyp

comments.text: And a 12x16 or 12x12 holes mount pattern could be fantastic for people with light setup
comments.author: Nabilus

comments.text: Yes you're right, i might consider this if i ever get back to the design table :)
comments.author: Nabilus

comments.text: Hi ! I printed one for my bonsai, but your motor mount is closer to the wing vs. the original plywood mount. I can't mount a 6" props and the 5" props are really close to the ailerons of each side. Is it possible to extend it a little 10 or 15mm and maybe more area to glue it to the wing. Thanks man
comments.author: Nabilus

comments.text:
Actually, a lot of people cut their elevons to get bigger props on. As for extending, it's likely you're using this to put a bigger motor on it, yes? So more weight, but being closer to center means not changing COG much, yes?
Otherwise, you can probably load this into something like onshape or other online editors and just stretch it from the motor plate to wherever you want. It's a benefit of this simple design actually, and inexpensive nature of 3D printing, you can play with it until your COG is perfect with your specific gear. :-)
comments.author: Nabilus
